revision.text:
'''Fine art nude photography''' is a [[genre]] of [[fine-art photography]] which [[Nude photography|depicts the nude]] human body with an emphasis on form, [[Composition (visual arts)|composition]], emotional content, and other [[aesthetic]] qualities.
The [[Nude (art)|nude]] has been a prominent subject of [[photography]] since its invention, and played an important role in establishing photography as a [[fine art]] medium.
The distinction between fine art photography and other subgenres is not absolute, but there are certain defining characteristics.
[[Erotic photography|Erotic]] interest, although often present, is secondary,<ref>{{cite book| author=Clark, Kenneth| year=1956| title=The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form|chapter=1. The Naked and the Nude|publisher=Princeton University Press| location=Princeton| isbn=0-691-01788-3 }}</ref> which distinguishes art photography from both [[glamour photography]], which focuses on showing the subject of the photograph in the most attractive way, and [[pornographic photography]], which has the primary purpose of [[sexual arousal|sexually arousing]] the viewer. Fine art photographs are also not taken to serve any journalistic, scientific, or other practical purpose.
The distinction between these is not always clear, and photographers, as with other artists, tend to make their own case in characterizing their work,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.krosenthal.com/photography.html|author=Rosenthal,Karin|title=About My Work|accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavondyss.com/silverbeauty/about.htm|author=Schiesser, Jody|title=Silverbeauty - Artist Statement|accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcusart.net/|author=Mok, Marcus|title=Artist's Statement|accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> though the viewer may have a different assessment.
The nude remains a controversial subject in all media, but more so with photography due to its inherent realism.<ref name="Met"/> The male nude has been less common than the female, and more rarely exhibited or published.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Weiermair, Peter |author2=Nielander, Claus |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Hidden Image: Photographs of the Male Nude in the 19th and 20th Centuries|publisher=MIT Press, 1988|isbn=0-262-23137-9}}</ref>
The use of children as subjects in nude photography is especially controversial.
==History==
===19th century=== <gallery mode=packed widths=220 heights=165 caption="Photography and the Traditional Arts"> File:Durieu 5.jpg|alt=Photo|Photograph by [[Jean Louis Marie Eugène Durieu]], Part of a series made with Eugène Delacroix File:Eugène Delacroix - Odalisque - WGA6225.jpg|alt=Painting|Odalisque (1857) by Eugène Delacroix (Oil on panel), a painting with similar pose File:Archives d'Éros Marconi 02.jpg|alt=Study|[[Gaudenzio Marconi]] made his living supplying ''académies'' to students at the [[École des beaux-arts]] in Paris File:Frank Eugene - Adam und Eva 1898.jpg|alt=Adam&Eve|Adam and Eve by [[Frank Eugene]], taken 1898, published in ''[[Camera Work]]'' no. 30, 1910 File:Marconi, Gaudenzio (1841-1885) - Nudo accademico.jpg|Nude by [[Gaudenzio Marconi]], 1841–1885 File:Pluschow Male nude.gif|[[Guglielmo Plüschow]] Male nude File:Gloeden, Wilhelm von (1856-1931) - n. 1189 (other version).jpg|[[Wilhelm von Gloeden]], Two male nudes outdoors c1900 </gallery> Those early photographers in [[Western culture]]s who sought to establish photography as a fine art medium, frequently chose women as the subjects for their nude photographs, in poses that accorded with traditional [[Nude (art)|nudes]] in other media. Before nude photography, art nudes usually used allusions to [[classical antiquity]]; gods and warriors, goddesses and nymphs. Depictions of male and female nudes in traditional art mediums had been mostly limited to portrayals as an ideal warrior or athlete (for men) or that emphasized divinity and reproduction (for women),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/nuan/hd_nuan.htm|title=Sorabella, Jean. January 2008. The nude in western art and its beginnings in antiquity. In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–.}}</ref> and early photographic art first engaged these archetypes as well. Poses, [[Photographic lighting|lighting]], [[soft focus]], [[vignetting]] and hand [[Photo manipulation|retouching]] were employed to create photographic images that rose to the level of art comparable to the other arts at that time.<ref name="Met">{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/press-room/exhibitions/2012/naked-before-the-camera|title=Naked before the Camera|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art}}</ref> The main limitation was that early photographs were [[monochrome]]. Although 19th century artists in other media often used photographs as substitutes for live models, the best of these photographs were also intended as works of art in their own right.
Nude photography was more controversial than painted nude works, and in order to avoid censorship some early nude photographs were described as "studies for artists",<ref name="Met" /> while others were used as references by artists to do drawings and paintings as a supplement to live [[Model (art)|models]]. [[Eugène Delacroix]] was an early adopter of the practice of using photographs taken specifically for him by his friend, [[Eugène Durieu]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Two Delacroix Drawings Made from Photographs|author=Van Deren Coke|journal=Art Journal|volume=21|issue=3|date=Spring 1962|pages=172–174|publisher=College Art Association|jstor=774417|doi=10.2307/774417}}</ref> [[Edgar Degas]] made his own photographs that he used for painting references.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=47047|title=After the Bath, Woman Drying Her Back|publisher=The J. Paul Getty Museum|accessdate=2013-05-18}}</ref>
===Modern=== <gallery mode=packed widths=220 heights=165 caption="Modern photography"> File:Alfred Stieglitz- Georgia O’Keeffe ,Hands and Breasts, 1919.jpg|alt=Stieglitz|''Georgia O’Keeffe, Hands and Breasts'' (1919) by [[Alfred Stieglitz]] File:KOPPITZ 0007.jpg|alt=Stieglitz|Nude study by [[Rudolf Koppitz]] (1927) </gallery> As fine art photography first embraced and then moved passed classical allegorical imagery, both male and female photographers began to use the male nude as another medium to examine issues of representation and identity, sexuality and voyeurism.<ref>Weiermair, Peter (Ed.). (1994). ''The male nude: A male view: An anthology''. Zurich: Edition Stemmle.</ref>
Photographing nudes (and particularly male nudes) became a way for women artists to engage the subject of “the nude” from the position of power traditionally reserved for male artists;<ref>Weiermair, Peter (Ed.). (1995). ''Male nudes by women: An anthology''. Zurich: Edition Stemmle.</ref> alternatively, nude self-portraiture allowed men to begin to re-evaluate accepted definitions of sensuality and masculinity by photographing themselves.<ref>Massengill, Reed. (2005). ''Self-exposure : the male nude self portrait''. New York: Universe.</ref>
==== Alfred Stieglitz ==== [[Alfred Stieglitz]] is a major figure in bringing modern art to America by exhibiting the new genre of art in his New York galleries at the beginning of the 20th century. He is known to the public perhaps more for his relationship with [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], whose nude photos he exhibited in 1921 while married to someone else.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 2, 2001|title=ART REVIEW: Proselytizing for Modernism|first=Michael|last=Kimmelman}}</ref> "Stieglitz used the camera as a kind of mirror. 'My photographs,' he wrote in 1925, 'are ever born of an inner need--an Experience of Spirit. I do not make ''pictures . . .'' I have a vision of life and I try to find equivalents for it sometimes in the form of photographs.' Often he would write of ''true seeing'' and of ''inness''. As O'Keeffe noted rightly, the man she knew so well was 'always photographing himself.'"<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 6, 1983|title=Looking Back at the Seer of the New - Alfred Stieglitz: The Man, The Battle, The Art|author=Paul Richard|page=L1}}</ref>
==== Imogen Cunningham ==== [[Imogen Cunningham]] began taking photographs in Seattle in 1905, in the soft-focused ''[[Pictorialism|pictorialist]]'' style popular at that time; but she is best known for the sharp-focused modern style she developed later. She is also attributed as the first woman photographer to take a nude photo of a man (her husband, [[Roi Partridge]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=Sampling Imogen Cunningham's Vibrant Diversity|author=Charles Hagan |newspaper=New York Times|date=13 Oct 1995|page=C27}}</ref> In the work of [[Judy Dater]], one particular photo, ''Imogen and Twinka'', became one of the most recognizable images caught by an American photographer. It features a 91 year old Imogen Cunningham and a nude [[Twinka Thiebaud]].<ref>Fallis, Greg. [http://www.utata.org/sundaysalon/judy-dater/ Judy Dater], Sunday Salon with Greg Fallis, UTATA.org</ref> The photo was the first adult full frontal nude photograph published in [[Life (magazine)|''Life'']] magazine, in 1976.<ref>''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine, Bicentennial Special Issue (1976) called: ''Remarkable American Women 1776-1976''.</ref>
==== Man Ray ==== After [[World War I]], [[avant-garde]] photographers became more experimental in their portrayal of nudity, using reflective distortions and printing techniques to create abstractions or depicting real life rather than classical allusions.
Beginning in the late 1920s [[Man Ray]] experimented with the Sabattier, or [[solarization]] process, a technique that won him critical esteem, especially from the [[Surrealism|Surrealists]]. Many of the central figures of Surrealism—[[André Breton|Breton]], [[René Magritte|Magritte]], [[Salvador Dalí|Dalí]]—followed his example in using photography in addition to other media. Other photographers, such as [[Maurice Tabard]] and [[Raoul Ubac]], were directly inspired by Man Ray’s techniques, while photographers such as [[André Kertész]] and [[Brassaï]] were indirectly influenced by his innovative approach to the medium.
==== Edward Weston ==== [[Edward Weston]] evolved a particularly American aesthetic, using a [[Large format (photography)|large format]] camera to capture images of [[Nature photography|nature]] and [[Landscape photography|landscapes]] as well as nudes, establishing photography as a fine arts medium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativephotography.org/artists/edward-weston|title=Edward Weston|publisher=University of Arizona, Center for Creative Photography|accessdate=2013-05-18}}</ref> In 1937 Weston became the first photographer to be awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship|John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Fellowship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ccp.uair.arizona.edu/item/234|title=Edward Weston Photographs|publisher=Center for Creative Photography at the University of Arizona Libraries|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725011346/http://ccp.uair.arizona.edu/item/234|archivedate=2010-07-25|df=}}</ref> For a famous example of Weston's work see: [[Charis Wilson]].<ref>{{cite book | author=Conger, Amy| title=Edward Weston: The Form of Nude|publisher=Phaidon Press|year=2006|isbn=0-7148-4573-6}}</ref>
==== Bill Brandt ==== [[Bill Brandt]] is best known for a series of nudes developed primarily between 1945 and 1961, that are both personal and universal, sensual and strange, collectively exemplifying the “sense of wonder” that is paramount in his photographs. Brandt’s work is unpredictable not only in the range of his subjects but also in his printing style, which varied widely throughout his career. This exhibition is the first to emphasize the beauty of Brandt’s finest prints, and to trace the arc of their evolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/1343|title=Bill Brandt: Shadow and Light|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art|accessdate=2013-05-18}}</ref>
==== Diane Arbus ==== Many fine art photographers have a variety of subjects in their work, the nude being one. [[Diane Arbus]] was attracted to unusual people in unusual settings, including a nudist camp. [[Lee Friedlander]] had more conventional subjects, one being [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] as a young model.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/12/madonna.photo.auction/index.html?iref=mpstoryview |title=Nude photo of Madonna goes for $37,500 |date=February 12, 2009 |publisher=CNN}}</ref> {{further|Ruth Bernhard|Harry Callahan (photographer)|Emmet Gowin}}
===Contemporary=== <gallery mode=packed widths=220 heights=165 caption="Contemporary photography"> File:Equus 1989.jpg|thumb|Equus 1989 by [[Sergio Valle Duarte]] File:Augusto De Luca - Nudes 1.jpg|alt=Nude Photo|Nudes (1980) by Augusto De Luca File:Re-reading of The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife 1988.jpg|thumb|Re-reading of The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife 1988, by [[Sergio Valle Duarte]] </gallery> The distinction between fine art and glamour is often one of [[marketing]], with fine art being sold through galleries or dealers in limited editions signed by the artist, and glamour photos being distributed through mass media.
For some, the difference is in the gaze of the model, with glamour models looking into the camera, while art models do not.<ref>{{Citation| author=Conrad,Donna | publisher=PhotoVision| title = A Conversation with Ruth Bernhard| newspaper = Vol. 1 No. 3| year = 2000 | url = http://www.photovisionmagazine.com/articles/bernhard.interview.html}}</ref>
Glamour and [[Fashion photography|fashion]] photographers have aspired to fine art status in some of their work. One of the first was [[Irving Penn]], who progressed from ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine to photographing fashion models such as [[Kate Moss]] nude. [[Richard Avedon]], [[Helmut Newton]] and [[Annie Leibovitz]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/exhibitions/annie_leibovitz/|title=Exhibitions: Annie Leibovitz: A Photographer's Life, 1990–2005|publisher=The Brooklyn Museum|accessdate=10 November 2012}}</ref> have followed a similar path with [[portrait]]s of the famous, many of them nude.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2006/feb/08/photography.art|title=Not naked but nude|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=12 November 2012|location=London|first=Jonathan|last=Jones|date=2006-02-08}}</ref> or partially clothed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2008/06/miley200806|title=Miley Knows Best|publisher=Vanity Fair|year=2008|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> In the post-modern era, where fame is often the subject of fine art,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/feb/22/andy-warhol-legacy-lives-on|title=Andy Warhol's legacy lives on in the factory of fame|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=1 November 2012|location=London|first=Alex|last=Needham|date=2012-02-22}}</ref> Avedon's photo of [[Nastassja Kinski]] with a python, and Leibovitz's magazine covers of [[More Demi Moore|Demi Moore pregnant]] and in [[Demi's Birthday Suit|body paint]], have become iconic. The work of [[Joyce Tenneson]] has gone the other way, from fine art with a unique, soft-focus style showing woman at all stages of life to portraiture of famous people and fashion photography.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joyce Tenneson|url=http://www.tenneson.com/content/bio|accessdate=2013-05-18}} </ref>
Although nude photographers have largely worked within established forms that show bodies as sculptural abstractions, some, such as [[Robert Mapplethorpe]], have created works that deliberately blur the boundaries between [[Erotic photography|erotica]] and art.
Several photographers have become controversial because of their nude photographs of underage subjects.<ref name="Photo Flap">{{cite web|url=http://reason.com/archives/1998/05/01/photo-flap|title=Photo Flap|publisher=Reason|year=1998|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> [[David Hamilton (photographer)|David Hamilton]] often used erotic themes,<ref>Hamilton</ref> but [[Jock Sturges]] celebrates the beauty of people in naturist settings without emphasis on sexuality.<ref name="Sturges, Jock and Phillips, Jayne Anne 1991">{{cite book |author1=Sturges, Jock |author2=Phillips, Jayne Anne |lastauthoramp=yes | title=[[The Last Day of Summer (book)|The Last Day of Summer]] |publisher=Aperture |year=1991}}</ref><ref name="Sturges, Jock 1994">{{cite book | author=Sturges, Jock |title=[[Radiant Identities: Photographs by Jock Sturges]]|publisher=Aperture|year=1994|ISBN=0-89381-595-0}}</ref> [[Sally Mann]] was raised in rural Virginia, in a locale were [[Nude swimming|skinny-dipping]] in a river was common, so many of her most famous photographs are of her own children swimming in the nude.<ref name="Mann1992">{{cite book | author1=Mann, Sally |author2=Price, Reynolds| title=Immediate family| publisher=Aperture| year=1992| ISBN=0-89381-523-3}}</ref> Less well-known photographers have been charged as criminals for photos of their own children.<ref name="Powell, Lynn 2010">{{cite book |last=Powell|first=Lynn|title=Framing Innocence: A Mother's Photographs, a Prosecutor's Zeal, and a Small Town's Response|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BWshU7qUi-0C|publisher=The New Press|year=2010|isbn=978-1-59558-626-1}}</ref>
[[Body image]] has become a topic explored by many photographers working with models whose bodies do not conform to conventional prejudices about beauty.<ref name="R.Michelson Galleries">{{cite web|url=http://www.rmichelson.com/artist_pages/nimoy/pages/MaxBeaut.htm|title=Leonard Nimoy: The Full Body Project|publisher=R.Michelson Galleries|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref>
==Issues==
===Public perception=== At the beginning of the 21st century, it has become difficult to make an artistic statement in nude photography, given the proliferation of non-artistic and pornographic images which taints the subject in the perception of most viewers, limiting the opportunities to exhibit or publish the images. When they appear in mainstream consumer magazines such as ''[[Popular Photography]]'', ''PC Photo'', and ''[[Shutterbug (magazine)|Shutterbug]]''; the editors receive sufficient negative response that they tend to reject the work of serious nude-image photographers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Deitcher|first=Kenneth|year=2008|title=A Figure Study Workshop|journal=PSA Journal|volume=74|issue=3|pages=36–37}}</ref>
===Children as subjects=== Several photographers have become controversial because of their nude photographs of [[Minor (law)|underage]] subjects.<ref name="Photo Flap"/> [[David Hamilton (photographer)|David Hamilton]] often used erotic themes in books such as ''[[The Age of Innocence (Hamilton book)|The Age of Innocence]]'',<ref>{{cite book | author=Hamilton, David |title=[[The Age of Innocence (Hamilton book)|The Age of Innocence]]|publisher=Aurum Press|year=1995|ISBN=1-85410-304-0}}</ref> which have caused controversy in both the US and the UK. [[Jock Sturges]] celebrates the beauty of people in [[Naturism|naturist]] settings<ref name="Sturges, Jock and Phillips, Jayne Anne 1991"/><ref name="Sturges, Jock 1994"/> and states that his work is not exploitative; however in 1990 the FBI raided his studio and made charges that were later dismissed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogallery.com/Sturges_Jock/sturges-bio.html|title=Jock Sturges Biography}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Photo Lab Sets Off FBI Probe : Art: Jock Sturges' photographs of nude families are at issue|date=July 5, 1990|author=Harold Maass|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> However, due to the local nature of US laws on the issue, books of both Hamilton's and Sturges' photos have been ruled obscene in the states of Alabama, South Carolina, and Colorado.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/mar/08/news/mn-26778|title=Child Porn Fight Focuses on 2 Photographers' Books|date=March 8, 1998|author=J. R. Moehringer|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2013-05-18}}</ref> A similar controversy emerged in Australia in 2008 when photographs by [[Bill Henson]] were taken from an exhibit due to complaints regarding nudes of a thirteen-year-old girl, but no changes were proved.
[[Sally Mann]] was raised in rural Virginia, in a locale where [[Nude swimming|skinny-dipping]] in a river was common, so many of her most famous photographs are of her own children swimming in the nude.<ref name="Mann1992" /> Less well-known photographers have been charged as criminals for photos of their own children.<ref name="Powell, Lynn 2010"/> Some writers characterize many of these images as sexualizing children regardless of artistic merit.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Sexualizing Children: Thoughts on Sally Mann|first=Mary|last=Gordon|journal=Salmagundi|issue=111|year=1996|pages=144–145|publisher=Skidmore College|jstor=40535995}}</ref>
===Body image=== [[Body image]] has become a topic explored by many photographers working with models who do not conform to [[Norm (social)|conventional]] ideas about beauty. [[Leonard Nimoy]], after many years photographing conventionally beautiful professional models, realized that he was not capturing individual personalities, so he created a series with women interested in "[[Fat acceptance movement|Fat Liberation]]".<ref name="R.Michelson Galleries"/> Sally Mann's more recent nudes have been of her husband, whose body shows the effects of [[muscular dystrophy]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Sally Mann at Gagosian Gallery|last=Kuspit|first=Donald|journal=[[Artforum]]|volume=48|issue=5|date=Jan 2010|pages=198–199}}</ref>
===Erotic art=== Many contemporary artists push the boundaries by having work with both aesthetic qualities and [[Erotic photography|explicit sexuality]]. Late in his life [[Robert Mapplethorpe]] created work that was controversial in part by being on display in Washington, DC in a gallery receiving public funds.<ref name="moral">{{cite journal|title=Art and the morality of the artist|last=Bernays|first=Anne|journal=The Chronicle of Higher Education|volume=39|issue=20|date=Jan 20, 1993|page=B1}}</ref> When a Mapplethorpe retrospective opened at the Cincinnati [[Contemporary Arts Center]] in 1990, [[Dennis Barrie]] became the first American museum director to be criminally prosecuted for the contents of an [[Art exhibition|exhibition]]. Although explicit photos were placed in a separate room with a content warning, Barrie was charged with "pandering obscenity" and showing minors in a state of nudity, but a jury acquitted Barrie and the Arts Center of all charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ummsp.lsa.umich.edu/content/mapplethorpe-cincinnati-controversy-myth-and-legacy|title=Exhibiting Controversy: From Mapplethorpe to "Body Worlds" and Beyond|publisher=University of Michigan|accessdate=2013-05-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130615164032/http://ummsp.lsa.umich.edu/content/mapplethorpe-cincinnati-controversy-myth-and-legacy|archivedate=2013-06-15|df=}}</ref>

{{COI|date=February 2017}} '''Ourboox''' is a free [[online]] platform for creating and sharing [[e-books|ebooks]] that incorporate [[writing|text]], [[image]]s, [[video]]s, [[puzzle]]s, [[map]]s and [[quiz]]zes.<ref name=ourboox>{{cite web |title= About Ourboox |url= http://www.ourboox.com/about}}</ref><ref name=geektime>{{cite web |title= OurBoox, the Israeli startup publisher looking to dust off your manuscript |url= http://www.geektime.com/2014/09/04/ourboox-the-israeli-startup-publisher-looking-to-dust-off-your-manuscript/ |date=September 4, 2014 |newspaper=Geektime}}</ref>
The Ourboox platform enables [[User (system)|users]] to add text in any [[language]] that is compatible with [[html5]], to add [[work of art|artwork]] in [[jpeg]], [[portable network graphics|png]], or [[gif]] [[file format|formats]], and to [[Compound document|embed]] various media content from other websites, e.g. [[YouTube]], [[Vimeo]], [[SoundCloud]] and others.<ref name="geektime" /><ref name=jpost>{{cite news |title= The virtues of going virtual |url= http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/The-virtues-of-going-virtual-408477 |accessdate=July 15, 2015 |newspaper=Jerusalem Post |date=July 15, 2015 |location=Jerusalem}}</ref><ref name=nocamels>{{cite web |title= Publish Your Own Books With ‘OurBoox’, The ‘YouTube’ Of Literature |url= http://nocamels.com/2015/02/ourboox-free-online-books-self-publishing |date=February 21, 2015 |newspaper=No Camels}}</ref>
Each e-book is identified by its own [[Uniform Resource Locator|URL]], and can be edited by the [[author]] even after it is published. The content on Ourboox is not protected by [[digital rights management]] (DRM), and can thus be readily [[Web indexing|indexed]] and searched by various [[Web search engine|search engines]].<ref name="ourboox" /><ref name="geektime" />
A feature of Ourboox is the use of a page-flipping script, which emulates printed [[book]]s. This feature is suited for either direction of reading – [[right-to-left]] and [[Writing system#Directionality|left-to-right]].<ref name="ourboox" /><ref name="jpost" />
Ourboox has gained popularly among [[teacher]]s and [[student]]s,<ref>{{cite web |title= Times Educational Supplement (TES) recommendation of Ourboox |url= https://www.tes.com/news/school-news/breaking-views/teachers-should-flip-their-dull-workload-focus-precious-moments |date=February 23, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Ourboox recommendation by the Israeli Ministry of Education |url= http://ecat.education.gov.il/ourboox}}</ref> and currently has over 16000 books in 24 [[language]]s and 94 [[Literary genre|genres]] as of February 2017.<ref name="ourboox" /> It was established by [[Mel Rosenberg]] and [[Ran Shternin]], and was launched in 2014.<ref name="ourboox" /><ref name="nocamels" />
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.ourboox.com Ourboox website]

{{Infobox building | name = Palace of Karabakh Khans | native_name={{lang-az|Qarabağ xanlarının sarayı}} | former_names = | alternate_names = | image = Khans Palace010.JPG | caption = Ruins of the palace as of September 2013 | altitude = | building_type =[[Palace]] | status = | architectural_style = [[Architectural school of Arran|Architecture of Azerbaijan]] | location = [[Shusha]], [[Azerbaijan]] {{flagicon|Azerbaijan}} | map_type = Azerbaijan | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = Location within Azerbaijan | coordinates = {{coord|39.766111|N|46.751111|E}} | address = | client = [[Karabakh Khanate]] | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | start_date = | completion_date = XVIII-XIX centuries | demolition_date = | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | architect = | other_designers = | references = }} '''Palace of Karabakh Khans''' ({{Lang-az|Qarabağ xan sarayı}}), is a historic palace located in north-east part of [[Shusha]], [[Azerbaijan]]. The palace belongs to the highly artistic palace buildings of [[Azerbaijani architecture|Azerbaijan]] of the 18th and 19th centuries. It is currently in ruined condition.<ref>Под общей редакцией М. А. Казиева. Азербайджан (Исторические и достопримечательные места. Город Шуша. Дворец карабахских ханов. Издательство АН Азербайджанской ССР. 1960.</ref> ==Design== The palace consisted of a large number of rooms located on two floors, and a large T-shaped main hall, which was the compositional center of the entire palace. This hall was separated from the external space by enormous lifting windows-web, widely used in palace, residential and religious construction in the 18th and 19th centuries on the territory of modern [[Republic of Azerbaijan]].
<gallery widths="200px"> File:Шушинский Ханский Дворец Дочери Хана.jpg|<small> Image of the palace on postal card of [[Russian Empire]]. </small> </gallery> ==See also==
* [[Palace of Shaki Khans]]

{{Infobox person | image = Pouran Derakhshandeh, Hush! Girls Don't Scream film screening and press conference (13911122025851574).jpg | caption = Pouran Derakhshandeh, 10 February 2013 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|3|27}} | birth_place = [[Kermanshah]], [[Iran]] | Residence = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | nationality = [[Iran]]ian | birth_name = Pourān Derakh'shandeh | spouse = | children = | occupation = film director, producer, screen writer, and researcher | notable_works = | influences = | influenced = | relatives = | alma_mater = [[Iran Broadcasting University]] | religion = | networth = | years_active = 1986–present }} '''Pourān Derakh'shandeh''' ({{lang-fa|پوران درخشنده}}) (born 27 March 1951 in [[Kermanshah]], [[Iran]]) is an Iranian film director, producer, screen writer, and researcher. Derakh'shandeh graduated in film directing in 1975 from [[Iran Broadcasting College|Advanced School of Television and Cinema]] (مدرسه عالی تلویزیون و سینما) in Tehran. She started her professional career by making documentary films for the [[Kermanshah]] Television and subsequently for the Tehran Television. Her motion pictures include ''Relationship'' (1986), ''A Little Bird of Happiness'' (1987), ''Passing Through the Dust'' (1988), ''Lost Time'' (1989), ''A Love Without Frontier'' (1998), ''Candle in the Wind'' (2003), ''Wet Dream'' (2005), ''Eternal Children'' (2006), and ''Hush! Girls Don't Scream'' (2013). At the time she began working at NIRT and Produced “Plague”; A documentary about plague disease in Kurdistan Province. Next year, she produced a documentary about the "Last Wednesday of the Year" ceremony custom in some areas of Iran, “End Wednesday” (1976). In 1978 she directed “Mineral Springs of Rah Haraz” and a trilogy documentary series about handicrafts in [[Kurdistan]] titled, “Moj, janamaz and sajadeh”, “Nazok kari” and “Short–napped coarse carpet”. The four-part “Synthetic and Natural Fiber” was a research documentary about thread, worsted cotton, silk and [[synthetic fiber]]. During 1979-1980, Derakhshandeh produced “The Wheels Whirl”. It examines economic and social depression and closed manufactures like Iran National. “Shokaran” focused on addiction. The 17-part documentary explores difficulties for women, men and children who are addicted to drugs, drug smuggling, and means of preventing drug abuse. The production lasted from 1980 to 1982. ==Memberships== * WIF - Women in Film. * IFP - Independent Feature Project. * CIFEJ - Centre international du film pour I'enfance et la jeunesse. (International Centre of Films for Children and Young People) * DG of Iranian Cinema. * WG of Iranian cinema. ==Academic experience== * Visual Communication, College of Social Sciences, Islamic Azad University, 1991-1999 * Film Production, College of Psychology and Educational sciences, Tehran University, 1999 Derakhshandeh has also led some college research. ==International participation== With the support of Farabi Cinema Foundation, Derakhshandeh participates at some local and international film festivals : {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * Jury Member of Short Film International Film Festival (2011) * Ava Handicap Film Festival (2011) * Jury Member of International Fajr Film Festival (2011) * Selection Jury International Fajr Film festival (2011) * International Children Film Festival (2009) * International Children Film Festival (2008) * International Cosar Film Festival (2006) * Select Jury member at 23rd Fajr Film Fest (2005). * Third Eye 4.Asian Film Festival, Mumbai (2005). * 3rd Pune International film fest (2005). * 19th Isfahan INTL children Film Fest (2004). * 34th Roshd INTL, Film Fest (2004). * 18th Isfahan children INTL Film Fest (2003). * Select Jury member at Varesh Film Fest (2003). * 3rd Olympic sports and TV Film Fest (2003). * IRIB collage Film Fest. * Milad Koosar Documentary Film Fest. * 12th Productions of provinces Film Fest (2003). * Oil Film Fest (2003). * Fourth Asian Film Fest in India (2001). * Cairo Children Film Fest (2001). * CIFEJ at 16th Isfahan INTL children Film Fest (2001). * (oozra) Woman Villager Film Fest.(2000) * Saabs '''RUCAPS''' (Riyadh University Computer Aided Production System) was a [[computer aided design]] (CAD) system for [[architect]]s, first developed during the 1970s and 1980s, and today credited as a forerunner of [[Building Information Modelling]] (BIM). It ran on [[minicomputer]]s from [[Prime Computer]] and [[Digital Equipment Corporation]] (DEC).
==Development== The system was initially developed by two graduates of [[Liverpool University]], Dr John Davison and John Watts in the early 1970s. They took their work to architects Gollins Melvin Ward ([[GMW Architects]]) in London in the late 1970s, and developed it whilst working on a project for [[Riyadh University]]. It became the Really Universal Computer Aided Production System (RUCAPS), and from 1977 was sold through GMW Computers Ltd in several countries worldwide.<ref name=Port>{{cite book|last1=Port|first1=Stanley|title=The Management of CAD for Construction|date=1989|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=9781468466058}}</ref> The term 'building model' (in the sense of BIM as used today) was first used in papers in the mid-1980s: in a 1985 paper by Simon Ruffle,<ref>Ruffle S. (1985) "Architectural design exposed: from computer-aided-drawing to computer-aided-design" Environments and Planning B: Planning and Design 1986 March 7 pp 385-389.</ref> and later in a 1986 paper by Robert Aish<ref>Aish, R. (1986) "Building Modelling: The Key to Integrated Construction CAD" CIB 5th International Symposium on the Use of Computers for Environmental Engineering related to Building, 7–9 July.</ref> - then at GMW Computers - referring to the software's use at London's Heathrow Airport.<ref>cited by Laiserin, Jerry (2008), Foreword to Eastman, C., ''et al'' (2008), ''op cit'', p.xii</ref>
RUCAPS was a significant milestone in the development of building modellers, selling many hundreds of copies during the early 1980s when CAD was rare and expensive, and introducing thousands of architects to computer aided design. It is regarded as a forerunner to today's BIM software,<ref name=Eastman1>{{cite book|last1=Eastman|first1=Chuck|last2=Tiecholz|first2=Paul|last3=Sacks|first3=Rafael|last4=Liston|first4=Kathleen |title= BIM Handbook: a Guide to Building Information Modeling for owners, managers, designers, engineers, and contractors |date=2008|publisher=John Wiley|location=Hoboken, New Jersey|isbn=9780470185285|edition=1st|pages=xi–xii}}</ref><ref name=Eastman2>{{cite book |last1= Eastman |first1=Chuck |last2=Tiecholz |first2=Paul |last3=Sacks |first3=Rafael |last4=Liston |first4=Kathleen |year = 2011 |title= BIM Handbook: A Guide to Building Information Modeling for Owners, Managers, Designers, Engineers and Contractors | location = Hoboken, New Jersey|publisher=John Wiley|edition=2nd |pages=36–37}}</ref> and is seen by some writers, e.g.: Jerry Laiserin, as the inspiration behind [[Autodesk]]'s [[Autodesk Revit|Revit]]:
:''While Autodesk Revit may not contain genomic snippets of Reflex code, Revit clearly is spiritual heir to a lineage of BIM "begats" — RUCAPS begat Sonata, Sonata begat Reflex, and Reflex begat Revit.''<ref>Laiserin, J. (2003) "[http://laiserin.com/features/issue17/feature02.php LaiserinLetterLetters]" (see Laiserin's comment to letter from John Mullan), ''The Laiserin Letter'', January 06 2003.{{unreliable source?|date=June 2015}}</ref>
RUCAPS was superseded in the mid-late 1980s by [[Sonata (building design software)|Sonata]], developed by Jonathan Ingram. This was sold to T2 Solutions (renamed from GMW Computers in 1987),<ref name=Port /> which was eventually bought by Alias|Wavefront<ref name=Day>{{cite news|last1=Day|first1=Martyn|title=Intelligent Architectural Modeling|url=http://www.caddigest.com/subjects/aec/select/Intelligent_modeling_day.htm|accessdate=15 June 2015|work=AEC Magazine|date=September 2002|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419072947/http://www.caddigest.com/subjects/aec/select/Intelligent_modeling_day.htm|archivedate=19 April 2015|df=}}</ref> but then "disappeared in a mysterious, corporate black hole, somewhere in eastern Canada in 1992."<ref name=Crotty>{{cite book|last1=Crotty|first1=Ray|title=The Impact of Building Information Modelling: Transforming Construction|date=2012|publisher=SPON/Routledge|location=London|isbn=9781136860560|page=71}}</ref> Ingram then went on to develop [[Reflex (building design software)|Reflex]], bought out by Parametric Technology Corporation ([[PTC (software company)|PTC]]) in 1996.<ref name=Crotty />
===Comparison with BIM=== In 1984, RUCAPS was described as a 2½ [[dimension]]al interactive system, closer to the philosophy of 2D interactive systems such as ARK/2 or DAISY,<ref name=Reynolds>Reynolds, R.A. (1984) ''Computer Methods for Architects'', Butterworths, London. pp 78-79.</ref> and concentrating on the rapid production of 2D drawings (plans, [[Elevation (view)|elevation]]s and sections). During the early 1980s, Ingram worked on a supplementary 3D file structure for RUCAPS, where, by running a separate program and with manual intervention, a flat 3D file could be generated, allowing the production of perspectives and images. RUCAPS did carry the 'weather vane' concept from UK-based Applied Research's Building Design System, BDS,{{efn|developed at Cambridge by Paul Richens; not to be confused with [[Charles M. Eastman|Charles Eastman]]'s Building Description System, also BDS}} now found in most modern BIM systems, but did not have interactive 3D windows or rule-based language - core characteristics of today's BIM applications.
==The system== RUCAPS was a building modelling system. It used the concept, introduced by BDS,<ref name=Reynolds/> of 2½ dimensional representation of components, straddling the divide between two dimensions (2D, i.e. flat) and three (3D). Here, all the elements of the design were placed in space in three dimensions, but each element, such as a window, door, chair or wall, was modelled in a series of 2D views. These views were of the plan and two elevations, each of which were drawn conventionally, as though on the side of a glass box. The "box" was then moved about the design and placed. By looking down on the model the plan view of the whole model was visible, and from the side just the elevation was seen. Because moving the component, or "box", moved both the plan view and the elevations for it, the plans and elevations remained in harmony, and designer's time was saved.
RUCAPS consisted of 38 different programs. For example, there was a program to generate the geometry for building components, another to assemble them into groups, and another to assemble those sub-assemblies into a model of the building. A dozen or more modules took care of printing, copying of floors, printing schedules, and so on. In the way of the time, the user directed operations by calling up the relevant program module rather than, as today, selecting from a menu.
A large computer screen displayed the building model. The screen, or sometimes two screens, was controlled from a keyboard for launching programs, and typing in coordinate data. Basic components were given several 2D views, from the top and sides. The information was usually coded onto A4 sheets of paper, and typed in as a series of coordinates. Once available to use in the building module, the components would be located using a large digitizer. This permitted a base drawing to be taped down, and used for locating the new components. The screen was then used to help ensure accuracy.
Along the bottom of the digitizer was a template with commands which could be selected as required, so the keyboard was often not required. Assembly was aided for many users by the familiar look of the large digitizer, which looked much like the drawing boards common at the time. To aid the process of aclimatistion, the digitizer was used with an electronic pen, which made placing components both quick and accurate.
MIni computers were used to power the system. Initially single-user, the system soon graduated to larger computers that could handle eight or more workstations simultaneously. The nature of building modeling systems is that very little information needs to be transferred from the database to the workstation, so performance levels were good despite what looks like limited equipment. Most early display screens were monochrome, but later RUCAPS systems were colour. All were using vector graphics, which was a step up from the earlier storage tubes. Plotters were large format and pen based, using amid of roller ball pens and Rotring wet ink pens of several thicknesses and colour.
RUCAPS was expensive, as was all CAD at the time, so its use was confined to large building projects. It was then necessary to have several people working on the same model. An early multi-user system was developed, allowing single building models to be worked on simultaneously by many people. It was a system that employed layers, where components were allocated categories allowing groups of them to be switched off or on when the drawings were produced. Layering allowed, for example, drainage to be printed separately from electrical components, but still maintained on the single model. No 3D was available in RUCAPS though a totally separate 3D modelling and perspective hidden-line program called AUTOPROD written by Col. Nigel Hitch was sold alongside RUCAP. There was no database or modelling connection of any sort between RUCAPS and AUTOPROD.
No clash-detection or calculations were undertaken on the model, but some hiding of one component by another was possible so that external walls showed on elevations while the internal elements were concealed in a 2½D fashion.
==Notes and references== {{notelist}} {{reflist|30em}}

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "character in Romeo and Juliet" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|character in Romeo and Juliet}} {{Other uses}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox character | name = Rosaline | image = Rosaline.JPG | caption = Rosaline in [[Franco Zeffirelli|Zeffirelli's]] ''[[Romeo and Juliet (1968 film)|Romeo and Juliet]]'', one of the few films to give her a visible role. | creator = [[William Shakespeare]] | play = [[Romeo and Juliet]] }} '''Rosaline''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|ɒ|z|əl|ɪ|n|,_|-|iː|n}}) is an [[unseen character]] and niece of Lord Capulet in [[William Shakespeare]]'s [[tragedy]] ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (1597). Although silent, her role is important. [[Romeo Montague|Romeo]] is at first deeply in love with Rosaline and expresses his dismay at her not loving him back. Romeo first spots [[Juliet Capulet|Juliet]] while trying to catch a glimpse of Rosaline at a gathering hosted by the Capulet family. Scholars generally compare Romeo's short-lived love of Rosaline with his later love of Juliet. The poetry Shakespeare writes for Rosaline is much weaker than that for Juliet. Scholars believe Romeo's early experience with Rosaline prepares him for his relationship with Juliet. Later performances of ''Romeo and Juliet'' have painted different pictures of Romeo and Rosaline's relationship, as filmmakers have experimented with making Rosaline a more visible character. == Role in the play == Before [[Romeo Montague|Romeo]] meets [[Juliet Capulet|Juliet]], he loves Rosaline, Capulet's niece and Juliet's cousin. He describes her as wonderfully beautiful: "The all-seeing sun / ne'er saw her match since first the world begun."''Romeo and Juliet'', I.2.99–100. Rosaline, however, chooses to remain [[chastity|chaste]]; Romeo says: "She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow / Do I live dead that live to tell it now."''Romeo and Juliet'', I.1.231–232. This is the source of his depression, and he makes his friends unhappy; [[Mercutio]] comments: "That same pale, hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, torments him so that he will sure run mad."''Romeo and Juliet'', II.4.4–5. [[Benvolio]] urges Romeo to sneak into a Capulet gathering where, he claims, Rosaline will look like "a crow" alongside the other beautiful women.''Romeo and Juliet'', I.2.365. Romeo agrees, but doubts Benvolio's assessment. After Romeo sees Juliet his feelings suddenly change: "Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight / For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night."''Romeo and Juliet'', I.5.59–60. Because their relationship is sudden and secret, Romeo's friends and [[Friar Laurence]] continue to speak of his affection for Rosaline throughout much of the play. ==Analysis== ===Name=== {{quote box|width=23em|"...Juliet on the balcony ponders Romeo's name and likens it to that rose that remains itself whatever it is called. Is Juliet that rose, and, thereby, Rosaline renamed?""|—Jonathan GoldbergGoldberg, Jonathan. ''Queering the Renaissance''. Durham: Duke University Press (1994), 221–227. {{ISBN|0-8223-1385-5}}}} Rosaline is a variant of Rosalind,"Rosaline". ''A Dictionary of First Names''. Eds. [[Patrick Hanks]], Kate Hardcastle, and Flavia Hodges. Oxford: Oxford University Press (2006). Oxford Reference Online. Retrieved 25 June 2007. [http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t41.e2755 Oxford Reference] (Registration required) a name of [[Old French]] origin: (''hros'' = "horse", ''lind'' = "soft, tender"). When it was imported into English it was thought to be from the Latin ''rosa linda'' ("lovely rose")."Rosalind". ''A Dictionary of First Names''. Eds. [[Patrick Hanks]], Kate Hardcastle, and Flavia Hodges. Oxford: Oxford University Press (2006). Oxford Reference Online. Retrieved 25 June 2007. [http://www.oxfordreference.com/views/ENTRY.html?subview=Main&entry=t41.e2754 Oxford Reference] (Registration required) Romeo sees Rosaline as the embodiment of the rose because of her name and her apparent perfections.Whittier, Gayle. "The Sonnet's Body and the Body Sonnetized in 'Romeo and Juliet'." ''Shakespeare Quarterly'' 40.1 (Apr 1989): 27–41.Lewis, Alan. "Reading Shakespeare's Cupid." ''Criticism'' 47.2 (Apr 2005): 177–213. The name Rosaline commonly appears in [[Sonnets|Petrarchan sonnets]], a form of poetry Romeo uses to woo Juliet and to describe both Rosaline and Juliet. Since Rosaline is unattainable, she is a perfect subject for this style; but Romeo's attempt at it is forced and weak. By the time he meets Juliet his poetic ability has improved considerably. [[Gender studies|Gender studies critics]] have argued that Rosaline's name suggests that Romeo never really forgets her but rather replaces her with Juliet. Thus, when Juliet cries "What's in a name? A rose by any other name would smell as sweet," she is ironically expressing Romeo's own view of her as a substitute for Rosaline. That is to say, Rosaline, replaced in name only by Juliet, is just as sweet to Romeo. Gender critics also note that the arguments used to dissuade Romeo from pursuing Rosaline are similar to the themes of Shakespeare's [[procreation sonnets]]. In these sonnets Shakespeare urges the man (who can be equated with Romeo) to find a woman with whom to procreate—a duty he owes to society. Rosaline, it seems, is distant and unavailable except in the mind, similarly bringing no hope of offspring. As Benvolio argues, she is best replaced by someone who will reciprocate. Rosaline reveals similarities to the subject of the sonnets when she refuses to break her vow of chastity. Her name may be referred to in the [[Sonnet 1|first sonnet]] when the young man is described as "beauties Rose." This line ties the young man to both Rosaline and Romeo in Juliet's "What's in a name?" soliloquy. When Juliet says "...that which we call a rose / By any other name would smell as sweet",Act 2 Scene 2 she may be raising the question of whether there is any difference between the beauty of a man and the beauty of a woman. Rosaline is used as a name for only one other Shakespearean character—the one of the main female figures in ''[[Love's Labours Lost]]'' (1598), although Rosalin''d'' is the name of the main female character in ''[[As You Like It]]''. Scholars have found similarities between them: both are described as beautiful, and both have a way of avoiding men's romantic advances. Rosaline in ''Love's Labours Lost'' constantly rebuffs her suitor's advances and Romeo's Rosaline remains distant and chaste in his brief descriptions of her. These similarities have led some to wonder whether they are based on a woman Shakespeare actually knew, possibly the [[Shakespeare's sonnets#The Dark Lady|Dark Lady]] described in his sonnets, but there is no strong evidence of this connection.Clarke, Charles and Mary Clarke. ''The Shakespeare Key''. City: Kessinger Publishing, LLC (2007), 651–652. {{ISBN|1-4304-6745-2}} ===Rosaline as plot device=== Analysts note that Rosaline acts as a plot device, by motivating Romeo to sneak into the Capulet party where he will meet Juliet. Without her, their meeting would be unlikely.Gray, Henry David. "Romeo Rosaline, and Juliet". ''Modern Language Notes'' 29.7 (Nov 1914): 209–212. Rosaline thus acts as the impetus to bring the "star-cross'd lovers" to their deaths—she is crucial in shaping their fate (a common theme of the play). Ironically, she remains oblivious of her role.Evans, Bertrand. "The Brevity of Friar Lawrence." ''PMLA'' 65.5 (September 1950): 841–865. ===Rosaline and Juliet=== {{quote box|width=23em|"Rosaline and Paris...are the subtlest reflectors of all...they are cast like a snake's skin by the more robust reality of Romeo and Juliet."|—Ruth Nevo, on the Rosaline-Juliet, Paris-Romeo comparisonNevo, Ruth. "Tragic Form in Romeo and Juliet". ''Elizabethan and Jacobean Drama''. ''Studies in English Literature, 1500–1900'' 9.2 (April 1969): 241–258.}} Literary critics often compare Romeo's love for Rosaline with his feelings for Juliet. Some see Romeo's supposed love for Rosaline as childish as compared with his true love for Juliet. Others argue that the apparent difference in Romeo's feelings shows Shakespeare's improving skill. Since Shakespeare is thought to have written early drafts of the play in 1591, and then picked them up again in 1597 to create the final copy, the change in Romeo's language for Rosaline and Juliet may mirror Shakespeare's increased skill as a playwright: the younger Shakespeare describing Rosaline, and the more experienced describing Juliet. In this view, a careful look at the play reveals that Romeo's love for Rosaline is not as petty as usually imagined. Critics also note the ways in which Romeo's relationship with Rosaline prepares him for meeting Juliet. Before meeting Rosaline, Romeo despises all Capulets, but afterwards looks upon them more favourably. He experiences the dual feelings of hate and love in the one relationship. This prepares him for the more mature relationship with Juliet—one fraught by the feud between Montagues and Capulets. Romeo expresses the conflict of love and hate in Act 1, Scene 1, comparing his love for Rosaline with the feud between the two houses:Bowling, Lawrence Edward. "The Thematic Framework of Romeo and Juliet." ''PMLA'' 64.1 (Mar 1949): 208–220. {{quote|Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.
Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
O any thing, of nothing first create!
O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health!
Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!
This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
Dost thou not laugh?}} [[Psychoanalytic criticism|Psychoanalytic critics]] see signs of repressed [[childhood trauma]] in Romeo's love for Rosaline. She is of a rival house and is sworn to chastity. Thus he is in an impossible situation, one which will continue his trauma if he remains in it. Although he acknowledges its ridiculous nature, he refuses to stop loving her. Psychoanalysts view this as a re-enactment of his failed relationship with his mother. Rosaline's absence is symbolic of his mother's absence and lack of affection for him. Romeo's love for Juliet is similarly hopeless, for she is a Capulet and Romeo pursues his relationship with her; the difference being that Juliet reciprocates.Krims, Marvin, "Romeo's Childhood Trauma?--'What Fray Was Here?'." ''PSYART: A Hyperlink Journal for Psychological Study of the Arts''. (November 1999) 3 article no. 991022. Reprinted in Shakespearean Criticism, Vol. 76. This does not seem likely seeing as his mother died of grief after his banishment, indicating that she probably loved him deeply. ==Performances== Rosaline has been portrayed in various ways over the centuries. [[Theophilus Cibber]]'s 1748 version of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' replaced references to Rosaline with references to Juliet. This, according to critics, took out the "love at first sight" moment at the Capulet feast.Marsden, Jean. ''The Re-Imagined Text''. Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, (1995), 87–88. {{ISBN|0-8131-1901-4}} In the 1750s, actor and theatre director [[David Garrick]] also eliminated references to Rosaline from his performances, as many saw Romeo's quick replacement of her as immoral.Branam, George C. "The Genesis of David Garrick's Romeo and Juliet." ''[[Shakespeare Quarterly]]'' 35.2 (July 1984): 170–179.Stone, George Winchester, Jr. "Romeo and Juliet: The Source of its Modern Stage Career." ''Shakespeare Quarterly'' 15.2 (April 1964): 191–206. However, in [[Franco Zeffirelli]]'s 1968 film version of ''[[Romeo and Juliet (1968 film)|Romeo and Juliet]]'', Romeo sees Rosaline (played by [[Paola Tedesco]]){{cite web| title =Romeo & Juliet (1968)| work =Yahoo! Movies| publisher =Yahoo!| year =2007| url =https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1800341348/cast| accessdate =28 June 2007 }} first at the Capulet feast and then Juliet, of whom he becomes immediately enamoured. This scene suggests that love is short and superficial. Rosaline also appears in Renato Castellani's 1954 film version. In a brief non-Shakespearean scene, Rosaline (Dagmar Josipovitch) gives Romeo a mask at Capulet's celebration, and urges him to leave disguised before harm comes to him. Other filmmakers keep Rosaline off-camera in stricter accordance with Shakespeare's script.Martin, Jennifer L. "Tights vs. Tattoos: Filmic Interpretations of 'Romeo and Juliet'." ''The English Journal'' 92.1 (Sep 2002): 41–46. Rosaline also appears in the 2013 film adaptation of Romeo & Juliet. Robert Nathan's 1966 romantic comedy, ''Juliet in Mantua'', presents Rosaline as a fully developed character. In this sequel, in which Romeo and Juliet did ''not'' die, the pair live ten years later in exile in Mantua. After they are forgiven and return to Verona, they learn that Rosaline is now married to County Paris, and both couples must confront their disillusionment with their marriages. Another play, ''[[After Juliet]]'', written by Scottish playwright [[Sharman Macdonald]], tells the story of Rosaline after Romeo dies. A main character in this play, she struggles with her loss and turns away the advances of [[Benvolio]], who has fallen in love with her. Macdonald's daughter, [[Keira Knightley]], played Rosaline in the play's 1999 premiere.{{cite web|last=Maxwell|first=Tom|title=Keira's helpful prompt| work =The Scotsman| date =20 July 2007| url =http://living.scotsman.com/performing.cfm?id=1135292007 |accessdate=27 May 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071201070555/http://living.scotsman.com/performing.cfm?id=1135292007 |archivedate = 1 December 2007}}{{cite web| title =After Juliet by Sharman McDonald| work =Plays| publisher =Acquis|url=http://www.acquis.org.uk/play_uk/macdonald_uk.html |accessdate=27 May 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928011634/http://www.acquis.org.uk/play_uk/macdonald_uk.html |archivedate = 28 September 2007}} The 2012 young adult novel "When You Were Mine" by Rebecca Serle sets Rosaline's story in a contemporary high school. Rosaline and Romeo (renamed Rob) have been best friends since childhood and are just beginning to fall in love when Rosaline's cousin, Juliet, moves back into town and sets her sights on Rob.Serle, Rebecca. When You Were Mine. New York: Simon Pulse, 2012. {{ISBN|1442433132}} Important character in sequel named "Plague on both your houses!" (1994) by [[Grigori Gorin]]. [[Still Star-Crossed]] (2017) – period drama television series created by Heather Mitchell and based on the book with same name by [[Melinda Taub]]. It follows Rosaline (played by Lashana Lynch). She and Benvolio of Montague are betrothed against their will by Prince Escalus, to end the feud between the two families. Both resolve to find a way to end the violence without having the union. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Romeo and Juliet}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rosaline}} [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1597]] [[Category:Fictional Italian people in literature]] [[Category:Unseen characters]] [[Category:Female Shakespearean characters]] [[Category:Characters in Romeo and Juliet]] [[Category:Fictional nobility]]

page.title: Saint Jerome and the Angel of Judgement

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | image= San Girolamo e l'Angelo del Giudizio - Jusepe de Ribera.jpg | title=Saint Jerome and the
Angel of Judgement | artist=Jusepe de Ribera | year= 1626 | medium=oil on canvas | height_metric=262 | width_metric=164 | city=Naples | museum=National Museum of Capodimonte }} '''''Saint Jerome and the Angel of Judgement''''' is an oil on canvas painting by [[Jusepe de Ribera]], signed and dated by the artist in 1626. It was produced as a display for a side chapel next to the high altar of the church of [[Santissima Trinità delle Monache]], which also housed Ribera's ''Earthly Trinity''. The religious order running the building was suppressed in 1813 and the canvas instead entered the Bourbon Collection and the [[National Museum of Capodimonte]] in Naples - it still hangs in the latter.AA.VV., ''Museo di Capodimonte'', Milano, Touring Club Editore, 2012, pag. 232. {{ISBN|978-88-365-2577-5}} It is typical of Neapolitan [[Caravaggism]]. The figure of an angel blowing a trumpet draws on the angel in [[Caravaggio]]'s own ''[[Saint Matthew and the Angel]]''. The work shows [[Saint Jerome]] producing the [[Vulgate Bible]], shown as a scroll on the floor in front of him. Behind Jerome is his typical attribute of a lion, whilst to his right are a skull and a book, both also attributes of the saint. == References == {{Jusepe de Ribera}} [[category:1626 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Jusepe de Ribera]] [[Category:Paintings of the National Museum of Capodimonte]] [[category:Paintings of Saint Jerome|Ribera]] [[category:Angels in art]] [[category:Books in art]] [[category:Skulls in art]] {{17C-painting-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2018}} {{multiple issues| {{COI|date=December 2016}} {{advert|date=December 2016}} {{unreliable sources|date=December 2016}} }} {{Infobox Architectural Practice |image= Shilpa Architects Planners Designers Pvt Ltd (logo).jpg |caption=Official logo |name=Shilpa Architects |architects=[[Sheila Sri Prakash]]
Pavitra Sri Prakash |board=[[Bhargav Sri Prakash]]
[[Sheila Sri Prakash]] |founded={{Start date|1979}} |awards=2003 DesignShare
2002 Builder's Association of India |significant_buildings=[[Cholamandal Artists' Village]]
[[Mahindra World City, New Chennai]] |}} '''Shilpa Architects''' is an international [[architecture]], design and planning firm that was founded in 1979 in [[Chennai]], [[India]] by [[Sheila Sri Prakash]].{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/12/10/women-not-aware-of-their-rights-at-work/|title=Women Leaders at Work Series|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=10 December 2013}} The firm was established as a proprietary firm and is the first architecture firm that was founded independently by a woman and has been continuously operated in [[India]].{{cite web|url=http://www.constructionglobal.com/magazine/issue?id=12486211/37022447|publisher=Construction Global Magazine|author=Tilly Sweet|date=July 2016|title=10 of the Most Influential Female Architects (pg 26)}} It currently operates offices in Chennai, [[Bangalore]] and [[Mumbai]], in [[India]] and in [[New York City]] and [[Chicago]] in the [[United States]] and provides urban design and master planning services. The firm's designs can be seen at [[Cholamandal Artists' Village]], [[Mahindra World City, New Chennai]], [[Paranur]] on [[GST Road]] and it is known for its work inspired by sustainable vernacular architectural practices as well as a sensitivity for society{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/08/21/stories/2009082158130200.htm | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Learn from rural architecture | date=2009-08-21}} and the built-natural environment. [[File:Sheila Sri Prakash delivering keynote address at 2013 Milan Design Summit.jpg|thumb|left|Sheila Sri Prakash is founder of Shilpa Architects]] [[Sheila Sri Prakash]] currently serves on the [[World Economic Forum]]'s Global Agenda Council on Design Innovation, as one of 16 leading experts from around the world that have been called upon to devise plans to improve the state of the world. She received her architectural degree from the [[Anna University School of Architecture and Planning]] in Chennai and completed an Executive Education program at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]].http://www.weforum.org/global-agenda-councils/sheila-sri-prakash She was also an International Fellow of Architecture at [[Ball State University]] in Muncie Indiana for her scholarly work on Indian Art, Architecture and Vaastu : The Indian Art of placement or [[Vastu Shastra]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bsu.edu/news/article/0,1370,-1019-42,00.html |title=Plans in place for Focus on Asia Week |publisher=Bsu.edu |date=2002-01-29 |accessdate=2010-12-14}} Since its inception, the company has grown to over 80 professionals and has operations across India and in the USA. The firm's designers have been invited to speak at several national and international forums{{cite web|url=http://cii.in/documents/TN%20Moves-%20Main.pdf |title=CII |publisher=Cii.in |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} such as the [[Confederation of Indian Industry]]. Shilpa Architects was instrumental in the institution of the Indian Green Building Council and continues to remain a member of that organization.[http://www.igbc.in/site/igbc/memberslist.jsp?firstletter=S ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913091357/http://www.igbc.in/site/igbc/memberslist.jsp?firstletter=S |date=13 September 2009 }} The firm is known for designing planning and architectural solutions that cater to the millions of underprivileged by delivering shelter through low-cost, durable, mass-construction techniques. In 1987 - the year of "Shelter for the shelterless" by the Shelter programme in Tamil Nadu state,{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0360-1323(91)90051-c |title= Shelter programme in Tamil Nadu state |last= |first= |volume=26 |journal=Building and Environment |pages=277–287 }} the firm was invited by the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board, Madras Metropolitan Development Authority and the [[World Bank]] to prototype a model that has since been adopted successfully in a large-scale format across [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[India]].{{cite web|url=http://lnweb90.worldbank.org/oed/oeddoclib.nsf/DocUNIDViewForJavaSearch/9984B971A856641D852567F5005D844D |title=Integrated Urban Projects: Experience in Ecuador, India, and Brazil - Independent Evaluation Group (IEG) - The World Bank Group |publisher=Lnweb90.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} Sheila Sri Prakash holds patents for innovative designs in structural and architectural elements for low cost yet improved quality of construction.{{cite web|url=http://www.sristi.org/globalgian/files/inventors_of_india_2006.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - inventors_of_india_2006.doc |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} In 2003, Designshare awarded Shilpa Architects a Recognized Value Award for its innovative design for educational infrastructure.{{cite web|url=http://www.designshare.com/index.php/projects/chengelpet-elementary/school |title=Chengelpet Elementary School : DesignShare Projects |publisher=Designshare.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} In 2008, the firm received the IAD Award.[http://www.iadawards.in/iad-awards-08/participants.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115195954/http://www.iadawards.in/iad-awards-08/participants.html |date=15 November 2009 }} ==Projects== Shilpa Architects has recently been called upon to restore some of India's archaeological treasures as one of the country's select few experts in architecture, design, restoration and preservation by the Archaeological Survey of India.http://www.asi.nic.in/pdf_data/List_Architects_Conservation_empanelled_with_ASI.pdf ==Expansion== The firm has diversified with subsidiaries in the investment & asset management space - through Nirmana Investments Pvt Ltd which was founded by [[Bhargav Sri Prakash]] - and in turn-key interior fit out solutions - through Stone Lotus - and delivers architectural designs internationally through an overseas subsidiary. Pavithra Sri Prakash has recently been inducted into the Board of the company and is an Architect and Urban Designer by profession. She received her undergraduate degree in Architecture from the [[Anna University School of Architecture and Planning]] in Chennai and completed her graduate degree{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.columbia.edu/workpage/work/courses/studio/urban-design-studio-v-urban-design-expanded-field?filter=50 |title=Urban Design Studio II 2003: Urban Design in an Expanded Field | GSAPPonline |publisher=Arch.columbia.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} in Architecture and Urban Design from [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City|New York]]. The company recently inducted Amrit Sahasranamam as the Chief Financial Officer. Amrit Sahasranamam has an undergraduate degree in Computer Science{{cite web|url=http://www.iit.edu/~iitugr/abstracts1998.htm |accessdate=3 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015195832/http://www.iit.edu/~iitugr/abstracts1998.htm |archivedate=15 October 2008 }} from the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]] and a [[Master of Business Administration]] from the [[University of Chicago]].{{cite web|author=Chicago GSB |url=http://www.chicagobooth.edu/alumni/alumniweekend/networking_c.aspx |title=Chicago GSB Alumni Weekend 2005 |publisher=Chicagobooth.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-12-14}} ===Reciprocity Wave=== The Reciprocity Wave, a program conceived by Sheila Sri Prakash, is a sculpture competition where students create art work with recycled materials to highlight social and environmental issues. Shilpa Architects have conducted three such initiatives, two in Chennai,{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/education/student/article1488425.ece|title=Reciprocity Wave art competition|author=Express News Service|date=5 March 2013|publisher=The New Indian Express}}{{cite web|url=http://chennaionline.com/City360/City-Feature/20132611102608/Artistry-flourishes-in-Reciprovative-waves-second-venture.col|title=Artistry flourishes in Reciprocity Wave's second venture|date=11 March 2013|author=Chief Correspondent|publisher=Chennaionline}} and one in Bangalore.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/being-the-change/article5190955.ece|title=Being the change|author=Nandini Sundar|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|date=2 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/360818/when-creations-castaways-had-messages.html|publisher=[[Deccan Herald]]|title=When Creations from Castaways Had Messages|date=2 October 2013|author=DHNS}} and one in Cubbon Park, Bangalore.[https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.601735996529956.1073741831.222453207791572&type=1 Event Images, Reciprocity Wave at Cubbon Park, Bangalore] ==See also== * [[List of architecture firms]] * [[List of architects]] * [[List of Indian architects]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.shilpaarchitects.com Shilpa Architects] * [http://www.spectrumconcepts.in/ Spectrum Concepts] * [http://www.cwd.co.in/seo-services-company-chennai.html Sri Hema Infotech] [[Category:Architecture firms of India]] [[Category:Companies based in Chennai]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1979]] [[Category:1979 establishments in India]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = The Art and Olfaction Awards | logo = Circle_logo_BLK_TRANS_250px.png | type = [[Non-profit]] | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Perfume]], [[Art]], [[Olfactory art]] | parent = [[The Institute for Art and Olfaction]] | foundation = 2013 | location_city = [[Los Angeles]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.artandolfactionawards.org/}} }}
'''The Art and Olfaction Awards''' are a non-profit award mechanism designed to celebrate excellence in international artisan, experimental and independent [[perfume]]ry and [[olfactory art]] through a yearly blind-judged competition.
== Mission ==
The organization states the following as its mission:
"''Awarded to just four perfumes and one experimental project a year, The Art and Olfaction Award is designed to raise interest and awareness for independent and artisan perfumers - and experimental practitioners with scent - from all countries. By shining a spotlight on perfumery’s most outstanding creators, we hope to help generate support for independent practices in perfumery as a whole. The Art and Olfaction Awards are a program of [[The Institute for Art and Olfaction,]] a 501(c)3 non-profit organization based in Los Angeles, USA.''"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artandolfactionawards.org/about-2/|title=About|date=2013-10-26|newspaper=The Art and Olfaction Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>
== History ==
The Art and Olfaction Awards were founded in 2013 as a program of [[The Institute for Art and Olfaction]] in Los Angeles. The first awards ceremony took place in April, 2014, at [[Goethe-Institut|Goethe Institut]] Los Angeles. At this first event, awards were given in two categories: Independent and Artisan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.perfumerflavorist.com/networking/news/company/Niche-Perfumers-Nab-Prizes-at-Art-and-Olfaction-Awards-257943561.html|title=Niche Perfumers Nab Prizes at Art and Olfaction Awards|newspaper=Skin Inc.|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>
In 2015, the awards expanded upon their existing categories by adding The Sadakichi Award for Experimental Work with Scent - named after the critic and writer [[Sadakichi Hartmann]] in honor of his failed scent concert from the early 20th century.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/art-and-olfaction-awards-what-did-qaddafi-death-smell-like|title=What Did Qaddafi’s Death Smell Like?|date=2015-04-23|website=The New Yorker|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> The Sadakichi Award was added as "a new category aimed at recognizing innovative uses of scent beyond the bounds of commercial perfumery"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.basenotes.net/features//3133-report-from-the-second-annual-art-and-olfaction-awards|title=Report from the second annual Art & Olfaction Awards ~ by Deadidol — Basenotes.net|website=www.basenotes.net|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> - joining the artisan and independent awards to create what was intended as a broad snapshot of the diversity and creative potential in the field of perfume.
The third annual Art and Olfaction Awards were held on May 6, 2016 at [[Hammer Museum]] as part of their [https://hammer.ucla.edu/programs-events/2016/05/third-annual-art-and-olfaction-awards-with-emcee-zackary-drucker/ public programming]. The expanded event was hosted by artist and producer [[Zackary Drucker]], and was free, open to the public, and live streamed on the internet. In an effort to better cement the award's international commitment, the fourth annual Art and Olfaction Awards take place in May 2017 at [https://www.silent-green.net/ Silent Green kulturquartier] in [[Berlin]]. The finalists are announced yearly at [http://www.esxence.com/ Esxence] in Milan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fragrantica.com/news/2016-Art-and-Olfaction-Awards-Finalists-Announced-at-Esxence-7780.html|title=2016 Art and Olfaction Awards Finalists Announced at Esxence ~ Art Books Events ~ Fragrantica|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>
The Art and Olfaction Awards were created as mechanism to impartially judge and promote work being done by artisan perfumers, independent perfume houses, and creative practitioners working with scent in the context of arts or experimental practices. Limited to artists, [[artisan]] perfumers and independent perfume houses (which they define as brands that are independently owned, or owned by another independently-owned company<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artandolfactionawards.org/submission/independent-award/|title=Independent Award|date=2014-09-17|newspaper=The Art and Olfaction Awards|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>), they are closed to larger-scale perfume releases - a space already served by [[The Fragrance Foundation]]'s [http://www.fragrance.org/fragrance-awards/ Awards].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fragrantica.com/news/The-ART-and-OLFACTION-AWARDS-5020.html|title=The Art and Olfaction Awards ~ Art Books Events ~ Fragrantica|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> In that capacity they have been compared<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mary-orlin/art-and-olfaction-awards_b_6248560.html|title=Art and Olfaction Awards Celebrates Artisan Perfumers {{!}} Huffington Post|last=WineFashionista|first=Mary Orlin The|date=2014-12-01|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> to the film industry's [[Independent Spirit Awards]]. Indeed, the awards were created based on founder Saskia Wilson-Brown's experience with film festivals:
"''The awards represented a chance to apply what I learned in the film festival world to the perfume world. In fact, we adapted many of the structures that go into running a film festival for the Art and Olfaction Awards, namely: Low entry fees, [...] unbiased judging (in many film festivals you are excluded from judging a film that you have a personal tie to), a diversity of judges, and a non-profit art for arts-sake motivation.”''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cafleurebon.com/inside-the-institute-for-art-and-olfaction-awards-an-interview-with-saskia-wilson-brown-perfume-without-politics/|title=Saskia-Wilson Brown {{!}} Cafleurebon - Perfume and Beauty Blog|website=www.cafleurebon.com|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>
Several further systems were put into place to ensure fairness, including blind, multiple-phase judging.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://colognoisseur.com/tag/2016-art-and-olfaction-awards/|title=2016 art and olfaction awards {{!}} Colognoisseur|website=colognoisseur.com|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref> The result was what Luca Turin called '[...]the only fluff-free fragrance contest in the world<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arabia.style.com/beauty/beauty-guide/best-spring-summer-2015-perfumes-moschino-toy-tom-ford-noir-extreme-skive-canoe-goods-luca-turin-review/2/|title=Luca Turin Reviews Moschino Toy and Tom Ford Noir Extreme {{!}} Style.com/Arabia|date=2015-04-20|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-15}}</ref>'.
There are two artisan category winners out of ten finalists, two independent category winners out of ten finalists, and one Sadakichi Award for Experimental Work with Scent winner out of five finalists per year. Winners each receive a golden pear statuette.
== Past Winners ==
'''Artisan Category Winners'''
"Calling All Angels", by April Aromatics, Germany - 2014 winner
"John Frum", by Aether Arts Perfumes, US - 2014 winner
"Eau de Céleri", by Monsillage, Canada - 2015 winner

'''Independent Category Winners'''

"Fathom V", by BeauFort London, England (with Julie Marlowe) - 2017 winner
"Eau de Virginie", by Au Pays de la Fleur d'Oranger (with Jean-Claude Gigodot) - 2018 winner
"Nuit de Bakelite", by Naomi Goodsir (with Isabelle Doyen) - 2018 winner
'''Sadakichi Award for Experimental Work with Scent Winners'''
"Famous Deaths", by [http://www.famousdeaths.nl/ Sense of Smell Project], The Netherlands - 2015 winner
"Century's Breath", by Cat Jones, Australia - 2016 winner
"Osmodrama / Smeller 2.0" by Wolfgang Georgsdorf, Germany (with [[Geza Schön]]) - 2017 winner

'''Contribution to Scent Culture Award'''
[[Christophe Laudamiel]] - 2017 winner
[[Peter de Cupere]] - 2018 winner
'''Aftel Award for Handmade Perfume'''
"Pays Dogon", by Monsillage, Canada - 2018 winner
== Past Finalists ==

== Past Judges == Past judges include [[Stefan Sagmeister]], [[Christophe Laudamiel]], [[Luca Turin]], [[Mandy Aftel]], Sarah Horowitz-Thran, [[Michael Edwards (fragrance expert)|Michael Edwards]], Annick Le Guérer, [[Katie Puckrik]], Andy Tauer, Helder Suffenplan, Andreas Wilhelm, Denyse Beaulieu, Mark Behnke, Matthias Janke, [[Steven Gontarski]], Antonio Gardoni, Ashley Eden Kessler, Bruno Fazzolari, Dana El Masri, Harald Lübner, Sherri Sebastian, Yvettra Grantham, Ashraf Osman, [[Caro Verbeek]], Kaya Sorhaindo, Kóan Jeff Baysa, Matthias Tabert, Simon Niedenthal, Allison Agsten, [[Bettina Hubby]], Brent Leonesio, Daniel Krasofski, Deji Bryce Olukotun, Hank Jenkins, James McHugh, Laura Johnson, Lizzie Ostrom (AKA Odette Toilette), Marcos Lutyens, Mark Allen, Miriam Vareldzis, Christopher Gordon, Grant Osborne, Neal Harris, Sarah Baker, [[Peter de Cupere]], Persephenie Lea, Sebastian Fischenich.

== References == {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}} [[File:Danza aldeanos Rubens lou.jpg|thumb|280px]] '''''The Dance of the Villagers''''' is a 1635 painting by [[Peter Paul Rubens]]. now in the [[Prado Museum]] in Madrid. It is closely related to ''[[The Village Fête (Rubens)|The Village Fête]]'', of a similar date and on a similar subject.
After Rubens' death, [[Philip IV of Spain]] sent his ambassador to buy paintings from the artist's estate - he bought this one for 800 florins and the king hang it in his summer dining room in the old [[Royal Alcázar of Madrid]]. It is now in the [[Prado Museum]].
==External links== *https://www.museodelprado.es/coleccion/galeria-on-line/galeria-on-line/obra/danza-de-aldeanos/
{{Rubens}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dance of the Villagers, The}} [[category:Paintings by Peter Paul Rubens]] [[category:1635 paintings]] [[category:Collections of the Museo del Prado]] [[Category:Dance in art]]
