revision.text:
'''Transitions''' in [[fiction]] are words, phrases, sentences, paragraphs, or [[punctuation]] that may be used to signal various changes in a story, including changes in time, location, [[narrative mode|point-of-view character]], [[Mood (psychology)|mood]], [[tone (literature)|tone]], [[emotion]], and [[pace (speed)|pace]].<ref>[[#Morrell|Morrell]], 2006, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qhufPkfjmXgC&pg=PA281-2 281-2].</ref><ref>[[#Polking|Polking]], 1990, p. 495.</ref> Transitions are sometimes listed as one of various [[fiction-writing modes]].
==Purpose== Transitions provide for a seamless [[narrative]] flow as a story shifts in time, location, or [[Point of view (fiction) | point-of view]]. They aid the internal logic of a story by moving readers from sentence to sentence, paragraph to paragraph, idea to idea, [[scene (drama)|scene]] to scene, and [[Chapter (books)|chapter]] to chapter with grace and ease.<ref>[[#Morrell|Morrell]], 2006, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qhufPkfjmXgC&pg=PA281-2 281-2].</ref>
==Types== Transitions in fiction may take any of several forms, including [[Chapter (books)|chapter]] breaks, [[section break]]s, and [[:wikt:summarization|summarization]].<ref>[[#Rosenfeld|Rosenfeld]], 2008, p. 258-265.</ref><ref>[[#Marshall|Marshall]], 1998, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=ziBORQpTMD0C&pg=PA137-8 137-8].</ref>
==See also== *[[Style (fiction)]] *[[Transitions (linguistics)]] *[[Writing]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
==References== *<cite id = Marshall>{{cite book|title = The Marshall Plan for Novel Writing|first = E|last = Marshall|publisher = [[Writer's Digest]] Books|location = Cincinnati, OH|year = 1998| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ziBORQpTMD0C&printsec=frontcover |isbn = 1-58297-062-9}} *<cite id = Morrell>{{cite book|title = Between the Lines: Master the Subtle Elements of Fiction Writing|first = JP|last = Morrell|authorlink = Jessica Page Morrell | publisher = [[Writer's Digest]] Books|location = Cincinnati, OH|year = 2006 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qhufPkfjmXgC&printsec=frontcover| isbn = 978-1-58297-393-7}} *<cite id = Polking>{{cite book|title = Writing A to Z|first = K|last = Polking|publisher = [[Writer's Digest]] Books|location = Cincinnati, OH|year = 1990|isbn = 0-89879-435-8}} *<cite id = Rosenfeld>{{cite book|title = Make a Scene: Crafting a Powerful Story One Scene at a Time|first = JE|last = Rosenfeld|publisher = [[Writer's Digest]] Books|location = Cincinnati, OH|year = 2008|isbn= 978-1-58297-479-8}}
[[Category:Writing]] [[Category:Style (fiction)|*]] [[Category:Fiction-writing mode| ]]

{{italic title}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2013}} [[File:VisionsBeforeMidnight.jpg|thumb|First edition (publ. [[Jonathan Cape]])]]
'''''Visions Before Midnight''''' is a selection of the television criticism written by [[Clive James]] during his first four years (1972–1976) as ''[[The Observer]]'''s weekly television critic. The selection begins with a piece on the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in Munich, and ends with a piece on the [[1976 Summer Olympics]] in Montreal. It was first published in 1977. The title derives from [[Sir Thomas Browne]]: ''Dreams out of the ivory gate, and visions before midnight.''
Before being contracted by ''Observer'' editor [[David Astor]], James had previously written one piece per month on television for ''[[The Listener (magazine)|The Listener]]'' and its editor, [[Karl Miller]], had been an important influence on James. He had allowed him to, "write a column which eschewed solemnity so thoroughly that it courted the frivolous. Like [[Georg Christoph Lichtenberg|Lichtenberg]] Karl Miller appreciated the kind of joke that unveils a problem: if your gags had a serious reason for being there, they stayed in." James explains in the preface: "Television was a natural part of my life. I loved watching it and I loved being on it. The second passion has since somewhat faded, but the first remains strong, and was very powerful at the time. I watched just about everything, including the junk. The screen teemed with unsummable activity. It was full of visions, legends, myths, fables. T.V was scarcely something you could feel superior to. It was too various. What I had to offer was negative capability, a capability for submission to the medium. I was the first to submit myself to [[Alastair Burnet]] and find him fascinating. No critic before me had ever regarded [[David Vine]] as a reason for switching the set ''on''."
In the preface James says that the idea of publishing a selection of his television criticism had been in his mind since speaking with [[Kenneth Tynan]] at a reception at the [[Garrick Club]]. Tynan had said he hoped James would publish some of his criticism but averred that, "A television critic would have to know everything, and who knows everything?" James had been lost for an answer at the time but in the Preface replies, "It isn't necessary to know everything – just to remember that nobody else does either."
==External links== * [http://www.clivejames.com/television/visions Visions Before Midnight] on Clive James' official website
[[Category:1977 books]] [[Category:Books about television]] [[Category:1970s in British television]] [[Category:Works originally published in The Observer]] [[Category:Television criticism]] [[Category:Jonathan Cape books]]

{{dablink|Wild World is also a former name for the [[Six Flags America]] amusement park in Largo, Maryland.}} {{dablink|For the Nintendo DS game see [[Animal Crossing: Wild World]].}} {{dablink|For the Bastille album see [[Wild World (album)]].}} {{Infobox song | name = Wild World | cover = Wild-World-cover.jpg | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Cat Stevens]] | album = [[Tea for the Tillerman]] | B-side = {{ubl|"Miles from Nowhere" (USA)|"Sad Lisa" (Germany)}} | released = September 1970 | format = [[7" single|7"]] 45 rpm | recorded = 1970 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Folk rock]] | length = 3:15 | label = [[Island Records|Island]] (UK/Europe)
[[A&M Records|A&M]] (US/Canada) | writer = [[Cat Stevens]] | producer = [[Paul Samwell-Smith]] | prev_title = [[Father and Son (song)|Father and Son]] | prev_year = 1970 | next_title = [[Moonshadow (song)|Moonshadow]] | next_year = 1971 | misc = {{Extra music sample |filename=Catwildworld.ogg| title="Wild World" |Type=single}} }} "'''Wild World'''" is a song written and recorded by English [[singer-songwriter]] [[Cat Stevens]]. It first appeared on his fourth album, ''[[Tea for the Tillerman]]'', recorded and released in 1970. == Song meaning== Stevens developed a relationship with actress [[Patti D'Arbanville]] and the two were a pair throughout a period of two years or so. During that time, he wrote several songs about her, including the song "Wild World." The song has struck many critics as being protective and caring{{Failed verification|date=January 2016}}; the artist's expression of love includes words like "Because I never want to see you sad girl, don't be a bad girl".{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/blurred-lines-the-worst-song-of-this-or-any-other-year-20131206|title=Rob Sheffield's Worst Song of 2013: 'Blurred Lines'|publisher=}} The song is in the form of the singer's words to his departing lover, inspired by the end of their romance. Stevens later recalled to ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'': "It was one of those chord sequences that's very common in Spanish music. I turned it around and came up with that theme—which is a recurring theme in my work—which is to do with leaving, the sadness of leaving, and the anticipation of what lies beyond."{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=291|title=Wild World by Cat Stevens Songfacts|publisher=}} Released as a single in late 1970, it peaked at No. 11 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.yusufislam.com/lifeline/10/a45dd1dc1476115ceb7fa21a45cbcd0f/|title=Yusuf Islam Lifeline 1970|last=Islam|first=Yusuf|year=2008|publisher=Yusuf Islam Official Website |accessdate=2008-11-09}} "Wild World" has been credited as the song that gave Stevens' next album, ''[[Tea for the Tillerman]]'', "enough kick" to get it played on [[FM radio]]; and Island Records' [[Chris Blackwell]] has been quoted as calling it "the best album we've ever released" to that date.{{cite web|url=http://majicat.com/articles/rock71.htm|title=Easy Does It|last=Scoppa|first=Bud|date=May 24, 1971 |publisher=Rock Magazine |accessdate=2008-10-28}} In November 2008, the ''Tea for the Tillerman'' CD was re-issued in a deluxe version which included the original demo of "Wild World". ==Cover versions== The song has been covered by many artists, with many of the [[cover version|covers]] becoming hits of their own. [[Jimmy Cliff]]'s version, released a few months after Stevens released the original version, reached number eight on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. Surprisingly, Stevens' version was not released as a single in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. Some of the subsequent covers have also been in the [[reggae]] style, indicating that they may be covers of Cliff's version, as opposed to direct covers of Cat Stevens' original arrangement. An example of this would be [[Maxi Priest]]'s version of the song. Recorded and released as a single in 1988, this version also did well on the charts, reaching number five on the [[UK Singles Chart]] and No. 25 on the [[United States|US]] ''Billboard'' Hot 100. In 1987, [[Jonathan King]] accused [[Pet Shop Boys]] of plagiarising the melody of "Wild World" for their UK No. 1 single "[[It's a Sin]]". He made the claims in ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', for which he wrote a regular column during the 1980s. King also released his own cover version of "Wild World" as a single, using a similar musical arrangement to "It's a Sin", in an effort to demonstrate his claims. This single flopped, while Pet Shop Boys sued King, eventually winning out-of-court damages, which they donated to charity.{{cite web|work=Independent|title=Editor-At-Large: He lured boys. He's a bully. Now he bleats|date=2 April 2005|last=Street-Porter|first=Jane|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/columnists/janet-street-porter/editor-at-large-he-lured-boys-hes-a-bully-now-he-bleats-530894.html}} On July 7, 2007, the song was performed twice at the [[Live Earth]] concerts. [[James Blunt]] sang it at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London, England, while [[Yusuf Islam]] (formerly Cat Stevens) himself sang it in [[Hamburg, Germany]].{{cite web|work=Rolling Stone|title=James Blunt covers Cat Stevens at Live Earth|date=7 July 2007|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/live-earth-14-1343829}}{{cite web|work=NME|title=International Report: Live Earth Hamburg|date=7 July 2007|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/international-report-live-earth-hamburg-20070707}} ==Chart history== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1970-71) !Peak
position |- |Canada ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Top Singles{{cite web|url= |title=Item Display - RPM - Library and Archives Canada |website=Collectionscanada.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=2017-04-04}} | style="text-align:center;"|14 |- |Canada ''RPM'' Adult Contemporary | style="text-align:center;"|32 |- |US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]]''Joel Whitburn's Top Pop Singles 1955-1990'' - {{ISBN|0-89820-089-X}} | style="text-align:center;"|11 |- |US ''Billboard'' [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary]] | style="text-align:center;"|21 |- |US [[Cash Box (magazine)|''Cash Box'']] Top 100[http://tropicalglen.com/Archives/70s_files/19710417.html Cash Box Top 100 Singles, April 17, 1971] |align="center"|18 |} {| class="wikitable" |- !Chart (2007) !Peak
position |- |[[UK Singles Chart|UK]] ([[The Official Charts Company|OCC]])http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/37679/cat-stevens/ | style="text-align:center;"|52 |- |} {{col-2}} ===Year-end charts=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Chart (1971) ! style="text-align:center;"|Rank |- |US ([[Joel Whitburn]]'s ''Pop Annual''){{cite book |last=Whitburn |first=Joel |date=1999 |title=Pop Annual |url= |location=Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin |publisher=Record Research Inc. |page= |isbn=0-89820-142-X}} | style="text-align:center;"|102 |- |US ''Cash Box'' [http://tropicalglen.com/Archives/70s_files/1971YESP.html Cash Box Year-End Charts: Top 100 Pop Singles, December 25, 1971] | style="text-align:center;"|98 |- |} {{col-end}} ==Mr. Big version== {{Infobox song | name = Wild World | cover = Mr._Big_Wild_World.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Mr. Big (band)|Mr. Big]] | album = [[Bump Ahead]] | released = 1993 | format = *[[7" single]] *[[12" single]] *[[CD single]] *[[CD maxi]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop rock]], [[ballad]] | length = 3:27 | label = *Atlantic | writer = [[Cat Stevens]] | producer = Kevin Elson | chronology = [[Mr. Big (band)|Mr. Big]] | prev_title = [[To Be with You]] | prev_year = 1991 | next_title = Ain't Seen Love Like That | next_year = 1994 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|Za9LY6Q3EuI|"Wild World"}}}} }} In 1993 American rock band [[Mr. Big (band)|Mr. Big]] released a [[pop rock]] [[ballad]] cover of "'''Wild World'''" on their third album [[Bump Ahead]]. The single charted at No. 27 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], No. 33 on the [[Top 40 Mainstream]] and No. 12 on the [[Mainstream Top 40]]. In Europe it was very successful, peaking at No. 4 in Denmark, No. 7 in Austria & Switzerland, at No. 10 in Norway, Sweden & Netherlands and No. 13 in Iceland. ===Critical reception=== The ''[[Gavin Report]]'' wrote about the song: "How many ways can a song be interpreted? In the case of Cat Stevens' 1971 smash there are at least three: The Catman's original, Maxi Priest, who gave it a reggae spin, and now Mr. Big's soulful, sensitive approach with a slight rock edge. Lead singer Eric Martin is powerful without overpowering the song."{{cite magazine|first= Dave |last= Sholin |title= Singles |magazine= [[Gavin Report]] |accessdate= 2018-04-15 |page=|url= http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Gavin-Report/90/93/Gavin-1993-09-10.pdf}} ===Music video=== The music video for "Wild World" was directed by Nancy Bennett.{{cite web|url=https://imvdb.com/video/mr.-big-1/wild-world|title=Wild World (1993) by Mr. Big|publisher=IMVDb.com|accessdate=2018-10-18}} ===Charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Chart (1993) !Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Austria|7|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Flanders|24|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- |align="left"|Canada ([[RPM (magazine)|''RPM'']]){{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/item.aspx?IdNumber=1499&|title=RPM (Nov 27, 1993)|publisher=RPM|accessdate=2018-03-13}} |align="center"|9 |- |align="left"|Denmark ([[IFPI Denmark|IFPI]]){{cite magazine|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Music-and-Media/90s/1994/MM-1994-01-08.pdf|title=Top 10 Denmark|work=[[Music & Media]]|date=1994-01-08|accessdate=2018-03-27|format=PDF}} |align="center"|4 |- |align="left"|Europe ([[Eurochart Hot 100]]){{cite magazine|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Music-and-Media/90s/1994/MM-1994-01-08.pdf|title=Eurochart Hot 100 Singles|work=[[Music & Media]]|date=1994-01-08|accessdate=2018-03-28|format=PDF}} |align="center"|19 |- {{singlechart|France|39|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Germany|24|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- |align="left"|Iceland ([[Íslenski listinn|Íslenski Listinn Topp 40]]){{cite web|url=http://timarit.is/files/12199142.pdf#navpanes=1&view=FitH|title=Íslenski Listinn Topp 40 (30.09.1993 - 06.10.1993)|publisher=Dagblaðið Vísir - Tónlist|accessdate=2018-03-13}} |align="center"|13 |- |align="left"|Japan ([[Oricon]]) |align="center"|56 |- {{singlechart|Dutch40|10|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Dutch100|11|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|New Zealand|39|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Norway|10|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Sweden|10|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- {{singlechart|Swiss|7|artist=Mr. Big|song=Wild World}} |- |align="left"|[[UK Singles Chart|UK Singles]] ([[Official Charts Company]]) |align="center"|59 |- |align="left"|US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] |align="center"|27 |- |align="left"|US ''Billboard'' [[Top 40 Mainstream]] |align="center"|33 |- |align="left"|US ''Billboard'' [[Mainstream Top 40]] |align="center"|12 |- |} ==Notable covers== * 1970: [[Jimmy Cliff]] * 1971: [[Claude François]] (Fleur sauvage) * 1971: [[Barry Ryan (singer)|Barry Ryan]] * 1971: [[Bette Midler]] * 1971: [[José Feliciano]] * 1971: [[The Ventures]] * 1971: [[Franck Pourcel]] (Instrumental version) * 1971: [[Sacha Distel]] * 1987: [[Jonathan King]] * 1988: [[Maxi Priest]] * 1989: [[SNFU]] * 1994: [[Wise Guys (band)|Wise Guys]] * 2001: [[Me First and the Gimme Gimmes]] * 2003: [[Skye Sweetnam]] ([[Billy S.]] - revision.text:
The '''Women's National Book Association''' ('''WNBA''') was established in 1917, as an organization to promote the role of women in the community of the book.<ref name=walker>The Women's National Book Association Walker, Belle M. The Bookman; a Review of Books and Life (1895-1933); July 1921; 53, 5; American Periodicals. pg. 428</ref> This organization includes twelve active chapters in the United States, network members outside regional chapters, and corporate sponsorships.<ref name="wnba-books.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org|title=WNBA|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref> WNBA is a broad-based, non-profit,<ref>US publishing 2008. (2008). London: Snapshots International Ltd. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/214295670</ref> 501(c)(3) organization offering three distinguished national awards and a longstanding history of literary activism.<ref name="wnba-books.org1">{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/about-wnba|title=About WNBA|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref>
== History == The organization started in 1917,<ref name=walker/> when women in the book industry were excluded from joining the professional organization, the Bookseller's League.<ref name="auto1">The Woman Citizen: A Weekly Chronicle of Progress. Published by The Woman's Journal. Woman and the Stream of Thought. December 6, 1919, vol. IV, no. 20, page 545</ref> Fifteen women met at Sherwood's Book Store in [[Lower Manhattan]] on November 13, 1917, and founded the Women's National Book Association as an organization to support and give voice to women in the book industry. The first President was Pauline Sherwood, of Sherwood's Book Store.<ref>Anonymous, Women in business, Woman's journal., 3/3 (1918), 53</ref>
The early organization's unique characteristic was that membership was open to women in all facets of the book world-publishers, booksellers, librarians, authors, illustrators, agents, production people - the only criterion being that part of their income must come from books.<ref name="auto1"/> Almost 100 years later, with ten chapters spanning the country from Boston to San Francisco and with Network members across the country, the Women's National Book Association continues its mission to champion the role of women in the world of words, with women and men who are professionals in the publishing industry, who are authors, or are advocates of literature as members.<ref name="wnba-books.org"/> The organization's newsletter, ''The Bookwoman'', was created in 1936 by [[Constance Lindsay Skinner]] and has had continuous publication to the current date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/bookwoman|title=Bookwoman|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref>
== Chapters == There are eleven active chapters in the United States:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/find-a-chapter|title=Find a Chapter|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref> * Atlanta (2016) * Boston (1954) * Charlotte (2009) * Greater Lansing (2017) * Los Angeles (1975) * Nashville (1955) * New Orleans (2011) * New York City (1917) * Greater Philadelphia (2016) * San Francisco (1968) * South Florida (2015) * Washington, D.C. (1978)
== Awards and contests ==
=== WNBA Award ===
*The WNBA Award is presented by the members of the Women's National Book Association to "a living American woman who derives part or all of her income from books and allied arts, and who has done meritorious work in the world of books beyond the duties or responsibilities of her profession or occupation."<ref name="pw.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.pw.org/content/ann_patchett_receives_women_s_national_book_award|title=Ann Patchett Receives Women’s National Book Award|work=Publishers Weekly}}</ref> The award was formerly known as the [[Constance Lindsay Skinner]] Award.<ref name="auto3">Woman, 90, Still Writing. Dobbin, Muriel. The Sun (1837-1987); February 23, 1958; ProQuest Historical Newspapers: Baltimore Sun, The (1837-1988)</ref><ref>Mrs. Van Doren Receives Medal Of Book Group: Constance Lindsay ...New York Herald Tribune (1926-1962); March 21, 1942</ref> *Winners have included Mildred C. Smith, co-editor of ''Publishers' Weekly'' (1944); Emily P. Street, Secretary of William Morrow & Company and Director of Sales and Advertising (1947); [[May Massee]], Director of Doubleday's Books for Children department from 1923-1933, and Director of the Junior Book Department at The Viking Press from 1933 until she retired (1950);<ref>Book Award Presented: Skinner Plaque Is Won by Publishing House Employee;New York Times (1923-Current file); March 22, 1947</ref> [[Dorothy Canfield Fisher]], author of ''Understood Betsy'' and one of the members of the original panel of judges for the Book-of-the Month Club (1951);<ref>Society Showcase Closes Its Doors And a Story of 37 Fabulous Years: A ...The New York Times. New York Times (1923-Current file); February 17, 1951; ProQuest Historical Newspapers: The New York Times (1851-2010)</ref> [[Fanny Butcher]], Literary Editor of the ''Chicago Tribune'' (1955); [[Bertha Mahony]], launched the first Bookmobile and founded ''The Horn Book'' (1955); [[Edith Hamilton]], author of ''Mythology'' (1958);<ref name="auto3"/> [[Pearl Buck]], Winner of the Pulitzer Prize in 1931 for ''The Good Earth'' (1960);<ref name="auto4">She's Booked for Literary Award. Ullmann, Nadine. Newsday (1940-1986); April 19, 1965; ProQuest Historical Newspapers: Newsday (1940-1985)</ref> [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] (1961);<ref name="auto4"/> [[Rachel Carson]], author of ''Silent Spring'' (1963); [[Blanche Knopf]], president of Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. (1966); [[Mildred L. Batchelder]], head of the American Library Association's office for library service to children and young people (1967); [[Ursula Nordstrom]], Children's book editor (1972); Margaret K. McElderry, Children's book editor (1975);<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/authors/obituaries/article/46150-margaret-k-mcelderry-dies-at-98.html |title=Margaret K. McElderry Dies at 98 |date=February 15, 2011 |work=Publishers Weekly}}</ref> [[Barbara Tuchman]], author of ''The Guns of August'' and a Pulitzer Prize Winner; [[Barbara Bush]] (1990); [[Doris Kearns Goodwin]], author of ''Team of Rivals'' (1998); [[Patricia Schroeder]], Former Congresswoman and President and CEO of the Association of American Publishers (2000); [[Nancy Pearl]], author, librarian, book reviewer, and radio talk show personality (2004); [[Ann Patchett]], author of ''Bel Canto'' and owner of Parnassus Books.,<ref name="pw.org"/> and Amy King, poet and professor and executive board member of VIDA: Women in Literary Arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vidaweb.org/announcing-the-2015-winner-of-the-wnba-award-womens-national-book-association-vidas-amy-king/|title=Announcing the 2015 Winner of the WNBA Award (Women's National Book Association) – VIDA's Amy King|work=VIDA: Women in Literary Arts}}</ref>
=== Pannell Award === This award was established by the organization in 1981 in honor of a longtime member, Lucile Micheels Pannell.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.wnba-books.org/wnba-awards/wnba-pannell-award-for-bookstores</ref> Pannell was a well-known librarian, author, and manager of the Hobby Horse Bookshop at Carson, Pirie, Scott, and Company department store in Chicago.<ref>By Alberita R Semrad. Written for The Christian,Science Monitor. "Purchase of 76-Year-Old Home Provides Place for Books and for Garden." The Christian Science Monitor (1908-Current file): 12. Jul 08 1948. ProQuest. Web. 14 May 2015</ref> Pannell founded the Chicago Children’s Reading Table and was the first bookseller to win the WNBA Award in 1949.<ref>Goodwin, Polly. "Magazine of BOOKS." Chicago Daily Tribune (1923-1963): 1. Mar 13 1949. ProQuest. Web. 14 May 2015 .</ref> The Pannell Award recognizes the work of booksellers, both general booksellers and those specializing in children's books, who creatively promote and encourage public interest in books.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
=== Eastman Grant === The Eastman Grant is a cash award given annually by the Women's National Book Association to a state library association based in a state in which the organization has a chapter. The Eastman Grant funds librarian professional development and training.<ref>http://www.wnba-books.org/wnba-awards/wnba-eastman-grantfor-librarians</ref> The grant honors Ann Heidbreder Eastman, a longtime member of the organization and national president, as well as a member of the American Librarian Association, where she held many leadership roles.<ref>http://www.ala.org/awardsgrants/womens-national-book-associationann-heidbreder-eastman-grant-0</ref>
=== WNBA annual writing competition === After years of celebrating published authors, extraordinary book women and others in the field, WNBA decided it is time to celebrate emerging writers. In 2012, the first annual writing contest was announced, for fiction and poetry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/contest|title=Contest|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref>
== United Nations affiliation == The Women's National Book Association has been a non-governmental organization (NGO) member of the [[United Nations]] since 1959.<ref name="wnba-books.org3">{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/united-nations-affiliation|title=United Nations Affiliation|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref> An NGO is defined as "any non-profit, voluntary citizens' group that is organized on a local, national or international level. Task-oriented and driven by people with a common interest, NGOs perform a variety of services and humanitarian functions, bring citizens' concerns to governments, monitor policies and encourage political participation at the community level."<ref name="wnba-books.org3"/>
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unic.org.pk/index.php?id=ngo|title=UNIC and Non Governmental Organizations (NGOs)|work=United National Information Centre, Islamabad}}</ref> The Association role ranges from emergency-relief donations (Indian Ocean tsunami 2004; Myanmar cyclone disaster 2008; Haiti Earthquake 2010) to annual fund-raising (Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF), from UNICEF USA campaign-awareness (The UNICEF Tap Project, Believe in Zero—24,000) to literacy advocacy for women and girls (UNICEF's Afghanistan Education Alliance).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicefusa.org/supporters/organizations/civil-society/partners/womens-national-book-association|title=Women's National Book Association|work=United States Fund for UNICEF}}</ref>
== National Reading Group Month == The Women's National Book Association launched National Reading Group Month in October 2007 as the premier event of its 90th anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreadinggroupmonth.org/about_history.html|title=History and Mission|work=National Reading Group Month}}</ref> National Reading Group Month augments the WNBA's mission to promote the value of books and reading. Through this initiative the organization aims to foster the values reading groups encourage: camaraderie, enjoyment of shared reading, and appreciation of literature and reading as conduits for transmitting culture and advancing civic engagement. The mission of National Reading Group Month is to:
* Increase public awareness of the joy and value of shared reading * Provide a time for reading groups to celebrate their accomplishments and plan for the future * Provide opportunities for individuals to join an existing reading group or start a new one * Encourage libraries, bookstores, and organizations to host special reading group events
In addition, the National Reading Group Month creates an annual [http://www.nationalreadinggroupmonth.org/ggr_selections.html Great Group Reads] list of recommended titles for book discussion groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreadinggroupmonth.org/ggr_selections.html|title=Great Group Reads Selections|work=National Reading Group Month}}</ref>
== Membership == Membership in the Women's National Book Association is stated as being open to anyone interested in the mission of the organization. Ten chapters of the organization are active. Each offers programs, events, and support through chapter affiliation through an annual membership fee established by each chapter. For those outside the location of a chapter, network membership is offered. Corporate or Sustaining Memberships are also available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba-books.org/membership-info|title=Membership Info|work=Women's National Book Association}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.wnba-books.org Women's National Book Association website] *[http://www.wnba-centennail.org Centennial website of the Women's National Book Association]
